review_title: Providence has some work to do
pros: Great entry level experience with EPIC Nice, caring people to work with Some jobs are remote
cons: Senior leadership bases hiring decisions on charisma and age rather than experience and merit. Low pay. They say that the benefits you receive make up for the lack of pay, but they don't. They pretend to care about diversity, equity, and inclusion, but are not willing to put their money where their mouth is. They expect POC caregivers to educate instead of finding a professional. Raises are only a few cents a year. Sometimes they will do a "market review" and you'll get a few cents more. If you're a capable employee, they will take advantage. You will end up picking up the slack for employees who don't pull their weight.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Anchorage, AK
pros: I was hired with no prior CNA experience or a certificate. This kept me anxious, however, management and everybody on the team was helpful and pleasant. They trained me with all the skills necessary for doing the job with the perfect mix of classroom time and hands-on learning. I work in the resource pool (kudos to management -- RP rocks!) and get to work in every unit that needs PCT's. They make an effort to schedule us to be in different places each day to keep things fresh, which originally was a concern for me (the appeal of rp). Most staff I see is not overly stressed or stretched. Ratios for nurses seem to be 4:1, while PCT ratios are on average 8:1. Again, I am delighted with my experience and while I was terrified to start with all the abuse that goes on in this industry, I am pleasantly surprised to see management that values your time and work. The support has been immense and wonderful.
cons: My starting wage as a PCT is around 17/hr for 3 days a week. This might sound like a lot but it is not for Anchorage. It's very rewarding work but it is difficult and 12 hour shifts will always be exhausting, so it can be demotivating when you can earn just as much by working at a McDonald's. As a nursing student (they hired me before I started school) the experience is invaluable, however, if you do not plan on pursuing a different career in healthcare this is not a good long-term career. Before working here, I had heard horror stories from a friend who is a mental health counselor. I haven't encountered anything she mentioned, but I don't work in her department.

It pays well, but prepare to be used and disrespected.

pros: Great team environment with super helpful hall mates. Charge and resource RN also super helpful - one of each is on each shift with no assignment. Private rooms make it much easier for parents to bond with infant and help with cares/holding. Charting is Epic. Can wear whatever scrubs. All milk is prepped by nutrition team in a sterile environment. All IV fluids are run by student externs in a sterile IV room (or by charge/resource if externs unavailable). Unit is heavily involved in the Vermont Oxford Network (VON), and always striving to follow latest and greatest evidence based practice. Awesome OT/PT team - constantly trying to ensure that infant care is developmentally appropriate! 66 bed unit. Level 3 side is separated from the level 2 side with a hallways but it’s all in the same unit (nurses typically work either side, some definitely have preferences). Ratios are 1:1 or 1:2 on level 3 and 1:3 on level 2 (will only see 1:4 sparingly if short staffed, though the last 2 years have been more busy/short staffed so they popped up more for a while and are back to normal). Level 3 does everything but cardiac surgery, ecmo, and trachs. Plenty of GI and neuro surgery, cooling kids, and micros 22+ weeks! They have a wee care team to take care of micros. Union hospital! Lunch breaks are rarely missed (unless you’re charge/resource).
cons: Usually a 5 year wait for a day shift position (not much RN turnover). And a 2-3 year wait for variable/rotating position (current rotation is one month of nights to about 3-5 months of days, varies based on unit needs). Only a con for those who want Days. They do have 1:4 ratios when short staffed on the level 2 side. Have had high management turnover lately.

pros: I've worked here for the past two years. In that time, COVID has changed the landscape much. When I started it was a very nurturing enviornment for a baby nurse to learn - I was accepted into the RN residency program in fall 2000 and it was an amazing place to learn and grow. Pay was about on par with local hospitals and benefit packages were sufficient.
cons: The largest problem has been that Providence (Everett) management has been at war with the nurse's union to the point where they increasingly do not communicate and work with the nurses (through our union) and slowly over time things have gone from bad to worse. I really saw how horrible our union was treated during contract negotiations when they offered the nursing staff a 1% raise and were going to take away benefits such as our EIB, or earned income benefits which are accrued and pay out when we are sick beyond the first set number of hours - a critical benefit that we had had in our contract. When I started, we enjoyed a 4:1 ratio of patients to RN on our orthopedic floor. Most of the Med Surg floors were similar. It has gone from that ratio to 5:1 and most recently to 6:1 as of February 2023. I finally left because I did not feel safe with the patient loads they were heaping onto the RNs. The company has been hemorrhaging nurses and has not incentivized them to stay with the company nor has it provided updates on how to remediate the problem. The CEO left a few months ago and the new CEO has not discussed staffing issues for several months and only emailed the employees to discuss how a TikTok video claiming the RN's had to take 8 patients one night was false (I've heard the video was accurate in that all the nurses called out the next day when they found out they were going to be given 8 patient loads a second time). While 6:1 ratios are the new normal there, 7:1 have happened here and there as well (as well as a very few 8:1 times). Providence has not discussed any plan with the workers on how to get out of this problem. They are loading the staff up with so many patients that they quit and leave and go to other jobs. We all know the CEOs and management make millions of dollars (despite being non-profit, or not for profit or whatever) and so it feels pretty slimy to work for an organization that really does not put it's frontline workers first. Providence may be the one reason that safe staffing legislation actually gets passed because it is becoming so dangerous to work there that people are leaving for safer environments. Many managers on the floors have left Providence now (we have lost three managers (all in the same position) recently and the position is once again open all within a year's time - the reason why? They also are not being told what is going to change to make things better and so mid-level managers are leaving. Now, take all this with a grain of salt because this is being posted on 2/2023 and things may change at any time, but I could not work with this organization until they own up to their mistakes, treat the RN's union with respect and dignity and see that they have squandered their value resources - their workers by not putting them as a priority. I genuinely wonder if the hospital will be able to stay open or will have to close floors in the future.

review_title: Providence- Doesn't follow their own mission
job_title: PATIENT RELATIONS Representative in Portland, OR
pros: - Pay is higher than what you may receive when working at an FHQ - I worked alongside with some really great people, a lot were very passionate about the patients they cared for and served. - Health insurance coverage wasn't bad, it could have been better, but I wouldn't mention it as a reason not to work for Providence.
cons:
- Pay is not equal to or greater than what you would receive at other large healthcare organizations/hospitals, for example, Kaiser 

- Sick pay- when I was employed in 2020, we were not allowed to access our earned sick pay hours until after we had first used 3 days worth of PTO hours. What kind of nonsense is that? I have to burn my PTO while I am sick, even though I have earned sick pay? It seems like this was an effort to discourage employees from calling out sick for the day, but what sort of message does this send to employees, really? We are going to punish you for taking care of yourself while you are ill? Even though we are a healthcare provider? This is one example where Providence talks the talk but doesn't walk the walk. Their whole mission is "easing the way" for patients and staff- how did this ease my way when I was out sick? 

- No specific hours set aside for vacation or holidays. PTO is one lumped pool, so for holidays you have to make sure you have enough time set aside in your bank. Otherwise, you could be in the negative. What an odd and unhelpful system. This may have changed since I left the organization, but I would recommend asking recruitment about this during your application process. - Hounding patients to pay, even when they should be receiving financial support or free care. I felt so many examples that were brought up in the recent NY Times article resonated with my past experience as an employee. I was forced to ask people about how they could pay for their children's specialist visits out in public in the lobby where others could hear. I have had mothers cry in front of me and others about how they cannot pay, but still was instructed to ask for a "good faith payment of at least 25 dollars". If they couldn't pay that, we asked for whatever they could afford. How is this caring for the poor and vulnerable, as the mission states? It has now come out in a more recent article that Providence will now be making an effort to refund patients who were wrongly charged (even sent to collections might I add), but this is only happening after they were called out by the NY Times. Really shameful in my opinion.

-Very challenging to get out of entry level positions. I had to eventually leave to see any career growth/development. I tried multiple times to ask for more responsibility, more training and more opportunities. I spent 3 years in an entry level position with a bachelor's degree and then a master's degree for the last year. Partially my fault for holding out hope for a promotion or new internal opportunity, I was loyal to a fault. Learned the hard way by wasting my own time. - Providence recently (about 3-4 years ago) outsourced their HR department to another country. This really highlights the point that how they treat and care for their staff is not top priority. When I was trying to transfer to another internal position, it was an absolute nightmare. I didn't have a point person to contact when I had questions about the process, pay or general questions. I understand that large companies often opt to outsource HR/Benefits, but the company they have chosen to partner with serves more as a barrier than a support in my experience. 

- Working for such a large organization, has its cons. I found that a lot of direction and messaging coming from the top felt out of touch with what was really happening in the clinics, this was especially the case during the pandemic. There was the occasional bonus pay (which is great but not enough- this was the standard amongst most healthcare organizations at the time) as well signs calling us "heroes", which I personally found patronizing as nurses and other staff literally risked their lives as they were underappreciated and underpaid. 

- From my experience, culture was very competitive, people were looking out for themselves mostly, but that was truer in the first clinic I worked in than the second, take this with a grain of salt. 

- Lastly, I would just advise any potential applicants to think twice about working for Providence. They really indoctrinate staff with the mission of "caring for the most poor and vulnerable" and "easing the way of patients and staff" but I feel like they are benefiting off/hiding behind the original mission from the founding Sisters and not really caring to make an effort to apply this to modern times or healthcare. Providence's messaging from the top constantly harkens back to the how they began and their heritage, but they have let greed blind them. I would love for them to truly reflect; "what would our founding Sisters say about how we operate today?"

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Santa Monica, CA
pros:
In theory they are working to improve issues. It meets basic standards and provides basic/routine support.
I like the work and my coworkers.
cons:
Salary is not competitive, with minimal raises (5k increase to annual salary after 2 years experience, then 2.5k increase every 5 years). 
There is no current action plan for how they plan to incentivize retention of employees given there is no financial benefit for staying with the company long-term.
Annual PTO time includes all holiday's and office closure days which can be misleading in how many true PTO days you have at first glance. 
Contracts are often left vague with verbal promises and assurances of role/expectations that are then retconned as the contract doesn't actually specify. 
High turnover of staff on all levels. 
Difficulty filling open positions. 
Even if we were to be staffed at all open positions (we are not) it's incredibly short staffed for the quantity of work required.

pros: I had great health insurance that was affordable.

The hiring process was a disorganized mess, which is when I should have washed my hands of this company. They will drop last minute requirements in your lap instead of telling you up front what documentation you will need to produce and when and where to do the health screenings.

The facility itself was toxic. I was bullied and harassed by my supervisor and another nurse. I eventually filed a grievance after putting up with it for far too long. I was promised they have strong anti-retaliation policies in place and that it was safe for me to file the grievance, but they lied about that and I was fired for things I supposedly did which never happened.

Also, they are stingy when it comes to obtaining supplies and tools we need for our job. The building is disgusting and in serious need of renovation.

review_title: Great coworkers. Lack of Pay. Lack of support. Terrible HR. Providence take over ruined St Joseph Culture
pros: Staff is typically competent and team oriented.
cons:
Due to Providence buying St Joseph there is a major culture shift and many people leaving. It went from supportive to bureaucratic overnight. 

A major issues is there no longer HR on campus. All grievances including simple things like fixing an error on a paycheck goes through a call center that cannot directly forward you to HR (wherever they are). For example, it took 6 wks and SEVERAL attempts to get them to fix an error they made on my paycheck. This is a small example of the daily hurdles. 

Without HR it’s almost impossible to discuss pay, grievances, disability, etc. I quit due to the serious lack of support and lack of pay. For the same job at another hospital my pay went up $13k a year. The managers tell staff they can’t help because they too have no support.

pros:
Gives you quality experience law enforcement agencies look for. Law enforcement agencies hold Providence security with good regards.

I can start by saying that the healthcare plan and HSA is a huge bonus to working for Providence. I pay almost nothing for my medical, dental and vision plans, dumping excess into my HSA and retirement.

The shift differentials for swing ($1.50) and grave ($3.50) are incredibly enticing, especially for anyone who's experienced working security elsewhere.

It's not contracted security and staff treat you with respect. It's a great feeling to be the one medical staff call in to solve issues and defuse volatile situations. In some considerations sometimes you have to play devil's advocate, bouncer or emotional support.

There's a dozen locations to work, you aren't bound to one hospital and you get to experience how different places are ran, if you don't choose to take a job at one location. There aren't only just hospitals to work at either (clinics, office buildings, mobile patrol).

The equipment issued is of moderate quality. Everything you carry is issued and paid for by Providence. Uniform policy is relaxed and more dependent on the location and supervisor. 

Providence provides it's own certification academy that gives you an idea and prepares you to work in a hospital. Providence pays for all the necessary certifications. Providence is investing more into training by directly showing us.

Providence covers you on on the job injuries and helps support you. Dealing with their 3rd party workers compensation is hit and miss.

Most of your coworkers in security are great people. It's easy to joke around and have fun with eachother.

The job itself is relatively easy. Most of the time you'll respond to dispatch calls or conduct proactive patrols. You're left up to your own on most occasions.
cons:
Non-unionized. Almost all of the medical and support staff have a union, security doesn't. It's hard doing your job when there's fear of reprisals coming from other department's unions. Providence expects us to enforce policy on staff that have more power than we do.

5 ON 2 OFF schedule. The schedule is terrible and doesn't give you enough time to decompress after stressful days. We're stuck on 5 day work weeks because the dinosaurs don't want 10s or 12s.

The job can be stressful trying to keep medical staff, co workers and supervisors happy. Sometimes you have to go against what someone wants, sometimes coming at a cost. If you aren't a politician you'll have to learn fast.

Some days you'll be running around all day, it isn't uncommon having no time to take a lunch. Providence only gives a 30 minute unpaid lunch with the expectation that you'll stay on campus "in case" anything happens.

Coming from security it was a big learning curve, especially how Providence wants things handled. Department policy is liberal but hard to balance politics between medical staff. There's lots of policy that needs to be understood, not including the legal requirements hospitals have to adhere to

You're expected to RUN to situations and fight when necessary. I wasn't used to fighting coming in the gate, it is a learning curve I'm still managing.

If you don't have interest in fighting or physically restraining people this isn't the job for you. It's a common occurrence that you'll have to deal with drunks, psychs, incredibly disrespectful people and very violent people. I have been spit on, bit and called unimaginable things from people ranging from children all the way to grandma's. If you can't control your emotions you'll end up hurt or without a job. Being able to talk to people should be a top priority when hiring people.

The police and jails send their problems to the hospitals. It's not uncommon to have police dump people off and run away.

You'll have frequent interactions with psychiatric patients. It's challenging and sometimes dangerous being placed into situations trying to balance safety for yourself, other staff and the patient. It can also get frustrating dealing with the same aggressive people. If you aren't prepared mentally it can be a rough learning curve. Sometimes medical staff don't understand your perspective, turning situations dangerous.

The pay and benefits aren't really aligned with the expectations and duties Providence has. The pay scale is all over the board, from $18/hr ranging to $25/hr starting. There are NO incentives to keep people interested in sticking around. The yearly raises don't even cover the rising cost of inflation. Other local hospitals offer higher wages to their security, some which don't even do half of what we do.

Some hospitals are giant high schools. Lots of gossip and general immaturity coming from medical staff and support staff. Learning to navigate and keeping your head down is challenging. It makes it even more difficult when you're an introverted person. It's not uncommon for guards to get fired after getting a little too comfortable around medical staff. Holding your tongue is a virtue.

If you aren't directly employed at a single hospital scheduling can be challenging. It wasn't uncommon to work double shifts or have quick turn arounds (graves to swings). It's expected that you work at every hospital in the portland area, which could mean working a few days on swing shift at the portland medical center and a day shift at saint vincent's.

Depending on the location, security managers and supervisors can be hit and miss. Some are genuinely great people, others not so much.

Training can be a stressful time. You'll be training at every location and evaluated on your performance. There is no way to learn everything about a hospital when you're not given very much time at locations, some you won't even return to for months or years.

job_title: Associate Mental Health and Wellness Clinician in Laguna Beach, CA
pros: It’s a huge network and you can transfer within the system easily after 1 year to anywhere there is a Providence.
cons: So many downsides! The pay is so low. Starting rate for me at 7 years of experience as an associate clinician providing therapy services and being a treating provider was $33. Then when I got licensed I got $35. The state average for a licensed social worker is $52 (I know this includes counties like Sam Francisco) but this company is off their rocker. The range for the mental health and wellness clinician is $32-55. The senior position makes $42 and the manager makes slightly more than that. You can have so many years of experience and none of their workers make anywhere near the mid to high range that’s offered by HR. It’s ridiculous. When a mass exodus happened the company’s response was to pay licensed clinicians $44/hour with no benefits for a 13 week contract because they couldn’t get full-time clinicians for the terrible rate they were getting paid. Additionally, upper management is incompetent. How are you going to tell me how to do my job, or make me do your job when you should be skilled in the roles of the departments you are managing. Upper management will not go to bat for you and they are surprised they can’t retain workers. For the salary they are offering they need to accept new clinicians from university and not expect much else.
